title: Leaderless Uber Scrambles to Prevent Employee Exodus
description: Uber’s senior managers have been urging its more than 15,000 employees to stick around and see how the embattled company reinvents itself after the ouster of its CEO.

title: From Music to Maps, How Apple's iPhone Changed Business
description: Apple’s iPhone, and the smartphone boom that followed, gave rise to whole new industries, laid waste to others and forced new business models. As the device turns 10, we take stock of its impact.

title: The New Sticker Shock: Plunging Cellphone Bills
description: There are more cellphones in America than people. That market saturation has led to brutal price competition, which in turn is transforming consumers’ costs, industry profits and antitrust law.

title: Uber Ex-CEO Travis Kalanick Knew of Stolen Google Files
description: Former Uber Technologies Chief Executive Travis Kalanick knew an engineer had allegedly stolen Google files before hiring the engineer last year, according to Uber’s attorneys.

title: Tesla Explores Possibility of Manufacturing Cars in China
description: Tesla said it is exploring with government officials in Shanghai the possibility of opening a manufacturing facility to build electric vehicles for the Chinese market.

title: Apple Scraps Like an Underdog in Second Biggest Mobile Market
description: Apple is helping third-party re-sellers, mulling new flagship stores and firing up app-development centers in India as it runs to catch up in one of the world’s biggest smartphone markets.

title: Facebook Has New Vision Beyond 'Connecting,' and It Thinks Groups Are Key
description: Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg took a step toward defining a new vision for the social-media company as it grapples with how to handle its growing power in the world.

title: BlackBerry Revenue Falls Amid Shift to Software
description: BlackBerry Ltd. stock plunged 11% in Friday trading after the company posted a steep drop in quarterly revenue as it continues to shift focus to its burgeoning software business.

title: Content Recommendation Firm Outbrain Lays Off 4% of its Workforce
description: Outbrain, best known for placing sponsored links on publishers’ websites, has laid off 4% of its roughly 600-person global workforce.

title: Trump Promises Telecom Executives Less Red Tape
description: President Donald Trump on Thursday told technology and telecom executives the government will tackle federal regulations they consider too restrictive but stopped short of announcing any specific policies aimed at their industries.

title: Taiwan's Foxconn Eyes Seven States for $10 Billion Investment
description: Taiwan’s Foxconn Technology Group, which assembles Apple’s iPhones in China, is looking at seven states in the American heartland where it would invest $10 billion or more in factories to build flat-panel screens.

title: Weibo Gets in Beijing's Way
description: Investors need to consider the political risk faced by China’s version of Twitter.

title: Apple Supplier Imagination Technologies Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: Imagination Technologies Group, a small U.K. technology firm which has been one of Apple’s important suppliers, said Thursday it has put itself up for sale.

title: Cable Operator Altice USA Climbs in Market Debut
description: Shares of Altice USA traded higher in their market debut Thursday, a day after the cable operator raised more money in its IPO than any other U.S.-listed telecom since 2000.

title: Oracle's Cloud Business Lifts Profit
description: Oracle Corp. said Wednesday its quarterly profit rose 15% from a year earlier  to $3.23 billion.

title: NBC Sports Jumps on the Esports Bandwagon
description: Comcast’s NBC Sports plans to televise an esports tournament later this summer, the latest broadcaster turning to competitive videogaming to grow viewership at a time when many consumers are cutting the cord.

title: Aviation Industry Seeks to Strengthen Cybersecurity Defenses
description: Escalating concerns about cyberthreats are prompting the aviation industry to devise an unlikely new safeguard: real-time warnings to pilots about potential hacking attempts.

title: Car Buyers Complain About Semiautonomous Features
description: J.D. Power’s annual Initial Quality Study, a closely watched indicator of which companies make the best cars and technology, found that buyers are increasingly dissatisfied with the semiautonomous features showing up on vehicles.

title: Virgin Mobile to Become iPhone-Only Carrier
description: Virgin Mobile, the phone carrier founded by mogul Richard Branson, will become the world’s first iPhone-only carrier.

title: Trump Administration to Rescind Obama's Foreign-Born Founder Rule
description: The Trump administration plans to dismantle a regulation that would have helped more foreign-born entrepreneurs build startups in the U.S. without a traditional visa, which could rankle Silicon Valley.

title: Tesla Replaces Chief of Self-Driving Software
description: Chris Lattner, who Tesla announced in January was hired from Apple Inc. as vice president of Autopilot software, has left Elon Musk’s Silicon Valley auto maker.

title: Tokyo Takes Lead in Toshiba Chip-Unit Sale Over China Fears
description: The Japanese government seized the lead role in buying Toshiba’s chip unit after expressing concerns about technology leaking to China, but a legal fight could hold up a deal.

title: The Economy Needs Amazons, but It Mostly Has GEs
description: When Amazon.com Inc. announced Friday it was buying Whole Foods, the stock market got a taste of something long missing: volatility. If Amazon is one extreme in how companies invest, General Electric is the other, writes Greg Ip.

title: Media Startups Try a Lower-Cost Model: Unpaid Student Writers
description: Chapter-based, for-profit media companies have been popping up in college markets across the U.S. As more traditional outlets struggle, these student-based sites have a lower-cost model to produce content—and revenue.

title: Amazon's New Wardrobe Service Is Latest Threat for Apparel Stores
description: Amazon.com is giving shoppers another reason not to visit stores. The online giant is rolling out a free service to let its Prime members try on clothes at home, its latest attempt to crack into the fashion world.

title: Where Bezos Leads, Amazon Shareholders Blindly Follow
description: Few companies other than Amazon could announce a $14 billion takeover of a mature firm, give no details of why they are buying the very business model they’re trying to disrupt, and have their market value rise by more than the takeover price.

title: Dear iPhone: I Love You. I Hate You.
description: As the Apple Inc. iPhone’s 10th anniversary approaches, Personal Technology columnist Geoffrey A. Fowler penned two letters to tell it how he really feels.

title: Wal-Mart to Vendors: Get Off Amazon's Cloud
description: Wal-Mart is telling some technology companies that if they want its business, they can’t run applications for the retailer on Amazon’s leading cloud-computing service, Amazon Web Services.

title: Toys Now Have Digital Eyes---Some Cool, Some Creepy
description: With the help of small LCD screens, digitally animated eyes are giving once-stoic toys—from race cars to Cabbage Patch Kids—a highly expressive makeover.

title: Big Prize in Amazon-Whole Foods Deal: Data
description: Amazon for years has been looking for more ways to gather information about how consumers shop. If its deal for Whole Foods goes through, the two companies can join their online and in-store knowledge.

title: How Technology Can Eliminate Traffic Congestion
description: Variable pricing has long been touted as a miracle cure for backups. Now we have the tools to make it happen.

title: The End of Car Ownership
description: Ride sharing and self-driving vehicles are going to redefine our relationship with cars. Auto makers and startups are already gearing up for the change.

title: Among the iPhone's Biggest Transformations: Apple Itself
description: Since Apple launched the iPhone in June 2007, the smartphone revolution it unleashed has changed the way people work and socialize while reshaping industries from music to hotels. It also has transformed the company in ways that co-founder Steve Jobs could hardly have foreseen.

title: Forget Mowing Lawns; Teens Make North of $20,000 Fixing Broken Phones
description: Some are earning north of $20,000 to fix those cracked screens and broken microphones.

title: Who Can Challenge the Google-Facebook 'Duopoly'?
description: Confronted with the market power of Facebook and Google, marketers and ad holding companies would welcome the emergence of a third power in digital advertising. But Amazon, Snap, Verizon and AT&T all have an incredibly long way to go challenge the “duopoly.”

title: Snap's Challenge: How to Grow Without Getting Awkward
description: The social-media company woos advertisers by promising them their ads will only appear beside content curated by editors and users. Now, it needs to grow.

title: Rural America Is Stranded in the Dial-Up Age
description: In many far-flung communities, where available broadband speeds barely surpass old-fashioned connections, residents sacrifice not only their online pastimes but also chances at a better living.

title: Google Will Buy Modular Homes to Address Housing Crunch
description: Google owner Alphabet Inc. is finalizing an order to buy 300 modular apartment units from a startup for a building likely to serve as short-term housing for employees.

title: Scientist's 'Tenacious' Research Paved Way for Breast-Cancer Treatment
description: When Angela Hartley Brodie first came up with a new way to treat breast cancer in the 1970s, there was little interest from the pharmaceutical sector. But her persistence over the years paid off.

title: Yuri Milner: Online Spending Will Fuel World-Wide Growth
description: Massive growth in online spending will help fuel world-wide growth in the technology sector in the next decade, Yuri Milner, founder of DST Global, said at The Wall Street Journal’s D.Live Asia 2017 conference.
